posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
World of Greyhawk Server Location Description and Files

Hail, fellow builders!

I have waited long enough for Kail to string together a more complete guideline / advertisement for our server, but it seems I have been left with the task after all. Not a problem, really, I LOVE that server, it's just that I though Kail could give a more complete explanation of it.

World of Greyhawk, or WoG as it's known, is a server that is based on a PnP book, containing many great adventurers that the core fans of RPG have at some point in their lives played, such as the Temple of Elemental Evil. Besides that, it's a great module, with many balance fixes, a list of which can be found at the server entrance, very good and challenging dungeons and very present and coherent DMs, as well as a fixed playerbase that can help many new guys.

PvP there is allowed, but in practice, not seen. people there prefer the co-operative style, and that has been made clear on many occasions, included when I myself suggested the addition of DM-administered tournaments for players to test themselves against one another. Farming is also frowned upon, and to some extent illegal, as you're not supposed to go to certain lower level areas unless you are of the appropriate level. ToEE (Temple of Elemental Evil, is an adventure for parties of 4 lvl 5 characters (with a maximum distance of 3 levels between each other, so you can't have a lvl 3, a lvl 5 and a lvl 8 toon in the same party, for example, because the lvl 3 guy would be out of the "range" of the lvl 8 toon) and it ends at around 12th-14th level. Soloing the place, you shouldn't be over level 20, maybe around 16 tops, as by then most monsters will give you very little XP.

There are many quests to be done there and areas to explore, and all quests that I have explored so far have been very well constructed and also hard to acheive. As an example, here are a few of them:

- The Old Moathouse (lvls 1-5, you can do it up to lvl 8 or so)
- The Kobold Lands (also low-level area)
- The Isle of Ruskis (also low-level, but very very hard for lvl 1 toons)
- The Temple of Elemental Evil - very long quest
- The Cult of the Dragon - long quest, but it can be done in three digesteable parts
- The Ghost Tower of Iverness
- The Great Northern Crusade (exploring the shield lands) - very big quest
- Defeating the Giants (Hill Giants, then Frost Giants, then Fire Giants) - also a big one
- Rary, The Traitor - Excellent Epic quest, but also very very time-consuming

And many many others. I won't spoil anything else, but there are many more quests or even places you can explore: Bandit Lands, Undermountain, The Underdark, Beyond the Underdark (you'll have to do it to know what lies within), Duergar Caves, Manscorpion lands, And even in these above quests, some have side quests that can be done while exploring the area, like White Plume Mountain and Castle Hart, when you're doing the Shield Lands, etc..

There are also many balance and sometimes bug fixes that have been implemented on WoG. The main thing is that WoG has an improved AI system that makes mages cast the proper spells, so if you let them buff, you're probably either going to take a dirtnap or use up a host of Heal potions. This server is in general not designed for beginners, and even some more experienced players that don't build properly may have a very hard time surviving there. AC is of UTMOST importance, as monsters will have a competitive AB throughout. AB isn't AS important, but is also relevant in some cases. Monster HP and saves are competitive throughout, so no easy way to Finger of Death or Wail of the Banshee your enemies unless you attack the monsters' weak saves. Monsters will use Hide and Move Silently and KD and Taunt when applicable, they will also commonly heal themselves. Bosses are TOUGH AS NAILS, there are no easy ways to kill them, well, none that I can share anyway .

Many spells have been altered in order to balance spellcasting a bit, so you may want to take a look at this list, but I won't list all of them, just the most important:

- Harm and Heal are capped at 250 damage.
- IGMS can hit a single target fewer times than the unmodified version (don't know the exact number)
- Blade Thirst lasts Turns / Level instead of Rounds / Level
- Darkfire and GMW can be cast on Arrows (giving them bonus damage), and GMW can be cast on Bows, adding the enhancement level and an equal amount as Mighty Property, so a lvl 15 GMW will add +5 to enhancement and +5 Mighty
- Epic Summon spells have been significantly powered up, but since monsters have as well, they're still comparatively weak.
- The regular Summon Creature spells have been redone. Now they last only 1 Round / level, but you can change the summoned creature type using a Book of Summons. That also applies to BGs and PMs Undead Summoning feats. Clerics of the Animal Domain and Druids have a summoned creature one level higher than normal, that is excellent, but what is different is that Summon Creature 9 will actually invoke a 10th level creature, which are the strongest summons in the game, except for Epic ones.
- Divine Wrath duration has been altered to go up the more levels you take of CoT.

As for Magic level, I would call it a mid-magic world, with a +6 enhancement cap (but you can't really find any +6 weapons, unless you're really really lucky). KD immunity is common in bosses, and some of them even have critical hit immunity. One of the coolest aspects of WoG is that you can use what is known as DM buys. Once every 5 levels you can buy a magic item with a power level according to your level, so Weapon Masters aren't completely screwed! Permanent Haste is RARE, except for the Scimitar of speed, but at level 35 you can DM buy an item with that property (but just that and nothing else). Another important thing is that they have a varied set of custom items, so, for example, you can have a Cloak of Wisdom and use a Ring of Wisdom and some other item to cap wisdom, so you aren't restricted regarding slots. You don't mandatorily need to use a Periapt of Wisdom. That's nice because mainly natural AC can only be attained through that slot. Also, they have Bracers of Shielding, which allow you to dual-wield much more effectively, as you won't lose much AC.

Overall, it's a HOME for me. I find that to be the most balanced world I have encountered in my online years. They really care about the game and enjoy playing it, and if you play there I hope you will come to agree with me. As for defects, there aren't many, but just so you don't call me byist, let me list a couple: Sometimes you will wait a very long time to get a DM buy, as the lead DM has a very busy RL, but now she has added a new DM to the staff, so things have improved. There is a Cleric / God alignment and Domain restriction system, so if you aren't of the correct alignment or have the correct domains for your god, you won't be able to lvl up as a cleric. Also, builds with conflicting alignments are illegal on WoG, so no Paladin BGs, or Monk Bards, or anything.

I might edit this post later if I recall any other relevant information, but many of our illustrious members are also WoG players, so perhaps you guys can add to this description in order to make it more accurate? Conlaoch, Grizzled_dwarflord, Kail Pendragon, Foojin, Mithril Jack and many others are among the regular players. If there's anything else I may have forgotten, I'm sure they'll mention it in no time!

Take it EZ!

edit: per Hip 20170517, added link to WoG requirements

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
The crafting system has also been enhanced.

The crafting system was developed by TK (The_Krit). This allows the level of the spells to scale up with the caster during crafting. Another nice addition is that all wands are automatically created with 50 charges. For instance, using Magic Missile as an example, we have the following chart.

Code: Select all

Spell                   Caster Level   Scribe GP   Scribe XP   Craft GP   Craft XP   Brew GP  Brew XP
Magic Missile                  3            75            3                2250         90           ---       --- 
Magic Missile                  5           125           5                3750        150           ---       --- 
Magic Missile                  9           225           9                6750        270           ---       ---
This means that as your caster grows, his crafting ability does as well. A lvl 13 wiz makes a wand that casts top rated Magic missiles. Thats 5 missile per charge. This scaling affects all of the spells available. Scrolls scale as well, so lets take Chain Lightning as an example.

Code: Select all

Spell                   Caster Level   Scribe GP   Scribe XP   Craft GP   Craft XP   Brew GP  Brew XP
Chain Lightning               11      1650          66         ---        ---       ---       --- 
Chain Lightning               15      2250          90         ---        ---       ---       --- 
Chain Lightning               20      3000         120         ---        ---       ---       ---
As its higher then a 3rd and 4th lvl spell, you'll notice that you can't craft or brew chain lightning, but it can be scribed. It also scales to lvl 20 when your caster is of a high enough level.

This adds a great amount of depth and versatility to your casters. It also makes it really useful to pick up the craft wand and scribe scroll feats on your clerics, druids, sorcs, bards and paladins.
Imagine a cleric that has a stack of Lvl 20 Hammer of the Gods to use as a diversion if things to badly, or a paladin with a wand of Bless Weapon or Divine Favor.

All of the spell changes and the crafting charts can be found in the Server Rules area of the WoG website. Just click here.


Conlaoch

posts.author: grom56
posts.content:
Hey all...
I wanted to add just a small bite to the large meal that Max laid out for you all in regards to WoG.   It's been my main home away from home for some 10 years now.  And I have yet to get tired of the place.   I play alot solo and have a weekly group that has been running pretty much since I started playing.  And even though we have been playing this long, we still get surprised on a run at times.   There's nothing like running head on into an area you thought you knew like the back of your hand...  only to find out that a DM has logged on and is now running your party through the wringer!
A good handful of the areas that Max made mention of have been put into place since I joined  and a few have opened up within the last few years.  The DM's like to keep us on our toes.   There has even been talk of new changes, fixes and areas in the works.

Also, as well as the places that Max mentioned, that are a few areas that while not really Quest areas, are large and have a few Quests in them. These being:

UnderMountain:  A very large place, with a few areas that scale very nicely.  I once took a toon from 1st level to 12th just running through this place.   You can go from a fight with Kobolds in one room, walk down a hall and find your self facing War Trolls...  Can be tricky, but much fun...  Just keep you eyes open for the old Dwarf Lord...  He's been wandering in there for years looking for his pants....

There is an Area that I call the Sand Lands (mainly because I always forget the true name for it) Which leads off into even more sandy areas...  All hot and tough.  Make sure ya bring water....  You can find some really tough Quests out in these areas, but some of the most fun is had in the places that have no Quests.

One last thing:  WoG was built by DM Raine to be a party world, it is very tough on a solo toon.  To make 5th level sometimes can be very frustrating to say the least.   The Moathouse and ToEE areas have clamed that down a good bit, but still...  Soloing can be tricky.  As GDL has been know to put it:  "Be sure to pack a lunch!"   

I look forward to seeing you all there!   And no matter where you play, remember:  Good Hunting!!

Grom

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Good upgrade that Monk level eh?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Its amazing. 1 monk level gives, to your forms:
- Extra AC from Wisdom which can be crazily buffed with Druid's Owl's Insight. At level 13 (D12/M1) I get +8AC from wisdom alone. Thats like a whole mundane full plate. Or 40% reduced enemy chance to hit, if their AB is within appropriate range of your AC.
- Further AC from tumble dump, (I took M1 at lvl 7, so +10 tumble = 2 more AC). +10 AC is approximately 50% reduced enemy chance to hit (give or take certain conditions).
- Extra attacks. at level 13 my bear does 4 attacks with flurry with like 34 strength. Without Monk I would only do two attacks. So basically doubles your damage output.
- +2 to all saves
- Cleave, Evasion and Improved unarmed strike feats for free.
- I did take skill dumps in Listen, Hide and Move Silently as well which Monk provides as a class skill, and Druid has an excess of skill points. So I can play as a stealthy monk bear if I want.

I read through quite a few 'dragon build' posts before I started playing druid. I seem to recall Kail Pendragon writing he wouldn't take any dragon / polymorph build without monk in it seriously and I can see why.

50% reduced enemy chance to hit (which improves as your wisdom increases) combined with doubled damage output = roughly quadrupled effectiveness of your polymorphed forms.

I finished the main quest for Borderkeep now (Goblin, Orc and Kobold chiefs defeated) and am looking for new areas to explore. I pretty much finished it as a Monk Bear with druid buffs.

I was thinking I could use further two levels of Rogue for skill dumps at 21 and perhaps 37. Having Search, Disable Trap, Spot, UMD, Listen and Tumble as class skills to skill dump into plus a little sneak attack damage just sounds too good to pass.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: I am considering playing the off-line version of WoG.  Reading that AC is king on WoG, here are some builds I am considering:
Hey Empyre65,
Unfortunately I'm not experienced enough on the module to comment but I thought I'd share with you this comment from KoL
Knight_oflimbo:
In my experience, you should rely on DR unless you can hit your level +25 in ac reliably(ie. 45 at 20, 55 at 30 and 65 at 40).  It is not easy to get a full set of DR gear (and AFAIK, you need to rely on gems to get enough blunt DR in any case), and will probably be out of reach for new players. If you are relying on DR, you also need some way to get immunity to crit, otherwise you can still die pretty easily to even normal enemies. 

There are also a handful of enemies that simply cannot be beaten by DR. Even with a build that revolves around DR will have trouble with WDK or Orcus. 
My own Lvl 21 Druid 20/Monk 1, even with ridiculous buffs to AC from maximum wisdom, Owl's Insight and Barkskin doesn't quite reach the targets recommended by KoL except in Water Elemental form. For example I think my AC is 38 in caster and bear form. I think I get to 47 AC with the Water Elemental but every monster seems to cast greater dispelling so I'm hesitant to use that form as a tank as my buffs are prone to be removed. I'm relying a lot on Greater Stoneskin and Premonition to survive, and whenever it wears off I re-cast it. If I wanted to reach the targets I could take Improved Expertise, but that comes at a cost of AB. I think the comment on immunity to crit is in regards to devastating critical being in the module.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
@ Orion, your AC for level 22-23 if you have played a comparable straight-up melee character, using the ever-popular rdd would be something like this:

10 (base) +5 (tumble) +1 (dexterity) +4 (rdd) +12 (full plate+4) +6 (tower shield+3) +4 (cloak of protection+4) +3 (amulet of natural armour+3) +2 (boots of hardiness+2) = 47AC.

That AC, for levels 22-23 is superb & will allow you to ignore most melee adversaries. If you need more AC than that for Boss fights, you could always use haste wands (preferably) or simply potions of haste in a pinch.

Of course, being an optimized build, your AB would also be more than average allowing you to also use "Expertise" and that would make you truly formidable in battle, as long as you take care of the mages first.

@Empyre, the first builds, NO. Just use one of the various & good rdd builds with scimmy & shield & Dev. Crit that you have & you should be fine, let's not exaggerate things too much here.

Post a couple of them here for good measure, so that we can review them & make some suggestions. Keep defences up & include "Expertise" as well.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Oh yes, she is good everywhere practically, but when we're talking about a particularly challenging PW (until you learn the ropes, at least) you should always sacrifice a modicum of power from all these power-builds in order to achieve more playability. You want to get the milestones of each build as soon as they are available, be it Bane of Enemies, Lasting Inspiration, Devastating Critical, EDR III, EWS, etc. depending on what your build's type is, because the journey to forty level is what matters the most & where you will spend most of your character's life.

So, always adjust the build to where you play & your preferences & particular playstyle. We are all here to help with any of these adjustements& offer constructive criticism where neccesary.

RE Search the unbuffed modified 10 search rank was suggested to me when I asked the players in the forum for advice about a whole bunch of skills. The Find Traps spell can add +10 to search (they changed the spell for balance reasons) and there is a helm which adds +8. So search 10 can be search 28 buffed up.  They said that should be enough to find the secret doors the DMs have hidden away are required to complete certain quests.

That being said I didn't put a single rank into Search in my build and there were some secret doors in the Moathouse (low level) as well as the Dragon Cult quest (late pre-epic) I was able to find with a modified search skill of 2 and still complete the quests.

RE traps and search I have died once by stepping on a trap which did 50-60 fire damage, but I was level 2 with 20 hp and in an area I shouldn't have been so I dont think that counts.

I've only explored a little of the Temple of Elemental Evil and I haven't been to Ruskis so I can't comment on those areas + search, but certainly Moathouse/Borderkeep/Pomarj/Hill Giants/Dragon Cult/Frost Giants my search skill has been more than adequate.

By the way I'm level 25. 5 more levels to dragon shape! Rejoice!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Empyre, both are strong builds, don't concern yourself too much with AB though, better build some of your defences. Epic Toughness, isn't a bad feat to take if you know you're gonna need the extra hit points somewhere.  In WoG, in high-level areas, there are many enemies that will throw Greater Ruin on you & that's enhanced there & does between 100-200 dmg a pop, in the light of that, more hit points are always good. You should also know that the heal potions in WoG are similar to Aielund (they heal about 250 hp's). That's not to say that melee builds with "just" 500 hp's won't survive there, merely a word of caution for those unfamiliar with the mod. Later on, you will be able to solo pure fighters should you want it.

Anyway, back to the build. Get something else instead of snake blood, "expertise" would still be my suggestion for that slot. Swap positions between  armour skin & epic prowess. Also, do that for your pre-epic feats, first should be IKD then IC & Toughness should be last or just before Gr. Cleave. Max-out your spellcraft by taking-out 15 points from search. Your UMD is good where is at, you can scroll-cast without failure by just being a Bard. I like that you're taking your milestone feats (Dev. Crit & EWS) earlier in your second build.

Note: This build suffers from extreme frontloading, it also suffers from a repetitive taboo feat, taken too many times.


THICK DWARF - With Dragon Blood
(Fighter 24/ Bard 6/ Red Dragon Disciple 10)

RACE: Dwarf
ALIGNMENT: True Neutral
PLAYABILITY: PvM 1-40

STARTING/ ENDING STATS:
STR –  16 (40)
DEX –  12
CON – 18 (20)
INT –   14 (16)
WIS –  08
CHA – 06 (08)

AB: +45/ +40/ +35/ +30 (Warhammer)
DMG: 1d8 +21/ 19-20 x3 (Warhammer)

Spellcasting: Use Magic Device, flawless scroll-casting
Devastating Critical DC: 45 (51)
Bard Song: 6/ Day, Lasts for 10 rounds each, +1AB/ +2 Dmg/ +1 to all saves/ +1 to all skills

LEVELING GUIDE:

One such way is by changing the five feats for hp's, you could have a complete secondary weapon.
He could also start with 9 Dex/ 19 Con, ending in 21 Con & EDR III.

I would also be tempted to slightly delay the acquisition of Dev. Critical & take Epic Fortitude/ Will, to further bolster his strong save Vs potential threats.
I would then use one of the taboo feats to take it resulting in a delay of two levels & the loss of 20 hp's but having +4 Fortitude/ Will.
His saves Vs spells are strong, no problems there.

Etc.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Critwall already? Get some screenshots from your fight with Arbas, will ya (in WoG's thread)?
I'm Druid 24/Monk 1 before the fight. Was pretty tough to fight my way into the fortress solo. Glorious and epic.

With the fight I spammed 3 storm of vengeances, grease and stonehold with 39 Wis and SF/GSF conjuration. I then fought Arbas and co my Summon Creature IX (who is a total boss with stoneskin, earthquake, improved power attack + my disables to drop enemy AC) and 9 - 10 casts of call lightning (I've still using some ring which gives me 1 bonus lvl 1-4 druid spell) in my spell book.

Pretty satisfying result! Thanks for helping with the build! Goes to show, a pretty close to pure build can work very well, and druid doesn't need to polymorph to be effective!

BTW RE the Nabassu creatures (shown dead on the last screenshot) were able to dispel one or two buffs including unsummoning my Summon Creature IX, as I'm caster lvl 24 I think they must have SF/GSF abjuration or something, or they are using breaches, or some other non-standard dispel ability better than greater dispelling... pretty clever design by the DMs if thats the case.. 

+2

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Stonehold is boss, it freezes almost everything. When you are at the level that you can combine it with SoV, it destroys the battlefield, well-played man.

It took me a while to recognize Arbas in this dungeon. So, they've put him inside eh? To be honest I liked him being in the open & charging at you at full speed atop of his destrier.

He will be a completely different experience when you go for him with another build.

I trust he still drops his hammer & plate armour? Both fine stuff for warriors.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Stonehold is boss, it freezes almost everything. When you are at the level that you can combine it with SoV, it destroys the battlefield, well-played man.
[...]
He will be a completely different experience when you go for him with another build.
I like the Stonehold/SoV/Grease combo, it forces out three saves (Will and Reflex) per round over a decent AOE, and elemental summons won't be affected by it, and to fully counter particularly with my sky high Wis scores and ESF:Conjuration (+4) one needs freedom, mind immunity and knockdown immunity. I could add entangle to the combo as well, but I find it is overkill. In parties I'll have to make sure teammates have freedom cast on them and possibly use entangle instead of grease (if they don't have knockdown immunity). I think SoV stacks, like Arbas and co. did die pretty quickly

Maybe it will be harder if I'm using Mogheiden against him, I'm sure. I've got her to level 6 or 7 now, so slowly getting there.

And I am making use of ESF:Necromancy for sure with FoD/Slay living, its great against enemies with low fortitude saves (rogues/mages). Drown is ok when it works. Harm is also super strong if I can hit them, even if its nerfed to 250hp damage, that is still sizable. 
It took me a while to recognize Arbas in this dungeon. So, they've put him inside eh? To be honest I liked him being in the open & charging at you at full speed atop of his destrier. 
That sounds awesome. 
I trust he still drops his hammer & plate armour? Both fine stuff for warriors.
Sorry I can't remember a hammer maybe there was one but I would have sold it. There was definitely a very nice light flail I think +3 or +4 or something, did additional negative energy damage (very nice!) but I couldn't use it, again sold it. There was some plate armor which was nice but I sold it. He has a shield which gives +char and allows you to cast greater eagle splendor (I think) and a ring which provides fear immunity and +char and persuade.  He and his henchmen dropped a lot of loot. I made sure I sold it in the Adventurer's Guild shop as most of it sold over 50k gold (I think many of the 'lesser' merchants have this as a cap). 

WoG now has a bank, so I've stashed over 800k gold in my account now. It's just protection in case I die on the battlefield, losing 10% of the gold being carried is a pain. I'm also scribing scrolls wherever possible, uses up some of this gold and its just so handy in case I use up all my prepared spells, to have 40-50 heal scrolls, 20-30 summon creature IX/premonition/stonehold/freedom/slay living scrolls in my bags etc etc I probably should also stash a few more FoD scrolls while I'm at it... I can't scribe SoV unfortunately (apparently this is a bug in the NWN core engine)

You know I never looked at such logs when I went through NWN OC/SoU/HoTU or Aielund for that matter, probably because I wouldn't die much, but in this PW its hard enough and one dies enough that it's worth the time and investment to think about how ones death can be prevented. 

A lot of deaths for me are being cocky and trying to tank thinking my AC of 40-50 odd is enough whilst spamming SoVs/Stoneholds and Call lightnings against huge mobs. The crab was a good example, although its funny as.

Adjusting on the fly is tough. I think the quickbar is key. I don't think anyone's done a guide on optimal quickbar usage in NWN and I can't find a lot out there. Honestly having a potion of heal / invisibility / speed on that quickbar can be a lifesaver, I nearly died again in that same dungeon from like a huge mob of stealthy rogues surprise backstabbing me, I had like 300hp and the bar just dropped down super quickly, when I popped that invis potion and was able to run a reasonable distance to escape detection. Great design by the way. Keeps players and parties on their toes. I imagine for a wizard, having that Time Stop scroll on the quickbar can be a huge lifesaver too.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Aquarius 233 wrote:As I am curious, I dare to ask a question: how can you reach such high WIS at level 25?
Hi Aquarius! Thanks for your comment and reading this thread! Very happy for you to ask a question! 

Firstly to clarify, I am character level 30 right now. I took every great wisdom feat available to me (including bonus feats from Druid) from level 21 onwards until character level 29. It allowed me to get Wisdom 30 at Level 29, and take the Dragon Shape feat at level 30.

My wisdom can be further buffed by a spell called 'Owl's Insight' which adds Wisdom of a value of half the druid level to a maximum of 12 (which is the cap). At level 24, the recipient reaches the cap. 

So yes I have wisdom 42 at level 29-30 when fully buffed! It makes my spell DC very nasty, and gives me a lot of AC from Monk Wisdom AC.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Found some new architecture in the swamp...


In all seriousness, I did get stuck for a while until I figured this puzzle out. 

Firstly I didn't click the respawn button immediately thinking I might have the option of selecting it later. I selected wait for help because I did want a few screenshots of this moment, and the menu was in the way. 

Normally when one dies you can select respawn later even if you initially click wait for help, but it isn't the case if you are petrified, which I learned later.

Thankfully I discovered the only action you can undertake whilst petrified is cancelling polymorph form. It allowed the enemies to kill me and allowed me to respawn. Ie. in dragon form my DR is 40/+6, the medusae couldn't do damage against me even if they critical hit me, in human form my DR is 0 (when premonition runs out)

So all is good in the world again and I have learned something!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Just like Mick said - that is the proper attitude!

They are tricky, both are immune to death spells (PMs), and together make a very potent team (Cleric/PM and Wizard/PM).

The normal "solo strategy" is to split them up - get a summons on one, and lure the other away.

I have always started with Lord Vayne himself, to be honest. He seems to be the most aggressive of the two at the beginning and tends to follow (Althea, a Gr. Boneheart of Iuz, likes to buff up first.)

Once one has dealt with Vayne, it is time for Althea.

She's tough, you will need to watch out for Mestil's (acid), her dispels, and she likes to throw around IGMS alot.

I normally like to use a lot of "run and gun" tactics, throw out some summons, and wear down her most potent spells.

Without her potent spells, you can pound her into bone dust!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Just a small correction for your AB, Orion.

It's a bit better than you think it is, because of the enchantment of your claws.

Here is how it goes: 24 (BAB) +23 (57 Str) +6 (Enchantment of your claws) -2 (Huge size) -2 (Flurry of blows) = 49AB.

If you have Epic Prowess, add one to that number. Bless & Aid potions will give you another couple of points. Finally, in wilderness areas, add another couple more.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Splendid work as ever, Aquarius! Much as in Mines of Twin Summits, you show us a path to glory.

Just as an incidental, if you fancy having another crack at Lolth (albeit her avatar rather than the real thing), you might consider the Aribeth's Redemption trilogy. It's an immediate follow-on from the OC and will take you from level 17/18 to 27/28. You will need to be male, human, elf, or half-elf, and of good alignment. For the sake of continuity, it would help if you let Aribeth live in the OC, but it's not mandatory. It is a good tying-up of loose ends from the OC, and takes you on an interesting journey as well (particularly if you've played Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 as well). You might have to bite down on impatience during the very wordy first part, but when it all gets going it really barrels along. And it finishes at just the right sort of level to then wander into Sands of Fate to get you up to level 40 with room to breathe. We have a thread for it in the Modules forum, and all is gettable from the Vault.

Cheers

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Greetings 19ACE81 and welcome to this forum! 

I have played WoG solidly for about 3-4 months. 

I progressed from the original Bioware campaigns, to Aielund (a single player campaign which you can access in the Steam Workshop or NWN Vault) and then to WoG after reading Maximillan Kane's post.

I find the server challenging and enjoyable, and it has enough epic level challenges for well designed level 40 characters, which I have still not fully experienced yet despite making three level 40 characters!

It isn't an easy transition from the original Bioware campaigns to the WoG world so be warned. 

Dying is an expected outcome so if it happens frequently, particularly early on, don't fret. Keep plugging away and dont get disheartened! 

If you aren't dying then either you are super skilled, the build is uber powered, or the area you are playing in is too easy for you :)

Low/mid/high magic? 

- Mid magic

What is max Armor/Dodge/Deviation AC or weapon enchantment you can get with no buff? 

- +5, there are extremely rare +6 items

What about stats? It'possible to hit the cap with items on all stats or not? 

- Realistically the stat cap can be reached with items for one stat. Might be reachable with more than one stat if you include spell buffs.

RP is needed or not? 

- Not necessary, it is an action based server, but it can be done. There is no role playing police running around so to speak.

- Alignment restrictions do apply to builds. It is not possible to have a Bard / Monk for example, or a Paladin / Blackguard.

What about pk/pvp? 

- PvP is allowed but not encouraged, as the server is designed for player versus monster.

- Excessive player killing by individuals should be reported in the forums, and further action can be taken.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Exp is stored on your character.

You can re-level your character.

There is a Releveling wand that can be bought from Chelina Rogerman in Borderkeep's Temple of Tritheron 

Or a Mulligan Stick can be bought elsewhere (from Hommlet, Ruskis, Adventurer's Guild).

Just be careful with your level one choices, and you can remake any character later if there are things that are not optimal. 

WoG forum is another good source of help. https://www.tapatalk.com/groups/worldofgreyhawkfr/

Lots of players have a whole pile of questions, and the player base and DM are extremely helpful, a lot of long-term very experienced players (Webshaman is one of them) acknowledge the challenges of the server for new (and old!) players but try to assist without 'spoiling' things. 

Feel free to search the forum to search for more info.

'Grom's threads' are excellent reads. I think there are four to five such threads, up to 100+ replies long :)

RE builds lots of builds here. Maximillan Kane, Valerfor and Kail Pendragon played WoG quite a bit and in the ECB archives, the Grizzled_Dwarflord and Cinnabar Din

Edit:
Clerics are strong in mid magic environments, of course. If you go cleric, animal and plant are the strongest domains for new players (there are certain deity restrictions you have to adhere to, which can be found on the WoG Website (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/index.html). 

If you do a lot of solo play, some light multiclassing with rogue to get search skills up is handy, as hidden doors can be easily missed by the soloist, or skill it up as a cross class + add an item with search in it

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I largely play WoG for a challenging environment playtesting my builds and that does include both action and RP elements and enjoyment etc. Agree wands of MM are very strong and only require UMD 1 to use.

Playtesting wise For example I have got my lawful evil Blackguard Executioner build to the mid 30s. He greets other players in the Adventurers guild with the most creepy sounding 'Hello' I could find in the voice pack, his battlecry is 'Your remains shall decorate my home'. Mind you, being lawful evil, he tries his best to 'conceal' his evil nature. 

For example:
Ashal Hald (my character): 'Do not be afraid, I am but a simple knight. 
Other player: 'Heh and I am a very clever mage'
Ashal Hald: 'The black garb I wear is simply the cladding of my very noble order' 
Ashal Hald: 'I perform a very simple task for my order with my curved blade, well below the dignity of my "betters", and boy do I *like* curved blades...'
Other player: 'And that might  be?'
Ashal Hald: 'Why execution of course! Time consuming to prepare the weapon, but required for maximum efficiency'
Other player: 'What a cheery thought to go to sleep on'
Ashal Hald: 'Oh I assure you I sleep quite well! Certain individuals have committed quite tremendous crimes in this world, heinous crimes in fact! Without their presence, the world is but a safer place...'

And so on and so forth

Combat wise whilst he can tank with 500 odd HP & heavy armor/tower he prefers to get his Vrock to take the damage whilst sneak attacking/critting/dev critting his enemies to death. Other cheese includes drinking an invisibility potion / use a ring of invisibility, creep up to an unsuspecting opponent, then suddenly Improved Knockdown/8d6 Sneak Attack/Critical hit for like 100 damage / crit hit with a keen scimitar +4 -> dead within a round.

Whereas my Professor of War is more  is 1v1 dueling. Meet my greatsword buffed with UMD etc at 50+ str / AB 60+, improved knockdown / improved disarm are my favorites. He still gets big 100+ damage crits as well. He was partying with a very noble paladin of Hoeder's, defeated a difficult opponent, and we discovered the enemy's lair and enormous amounts of treasure. 

The noble paladin stated 'The treasure is yours, a good deed is its own reward'. 
Whereas my Professor stated 'I am but an academic and I have a simple lifestyle which my professorial salary covers. Please the treasure is yours, even Paladins have operating costs?'. 

I think in the end we both left the area, leaving the treasure behind!

I try not to speed level, like I mean if I'm in a hurry sure it can be done, perhaps I can't do it as well as the others, but I do want to experience what it is like playing at low levels with my character, and if it isn't enjoyable I will make some adjustments to the character. For example with my Blackguard Executioner I discovered taking 8 levels of rogue as a high strength low dex build is not fun when you can only wear light armor, no shield, and run around with 13 AC, to level him required UMD, so I made adjustments to the build to take fighter earlier, and it was much more playable. He could still use UMD, but it wasn't required with full plate / tower to protect him.

So yes I try to experience all aspects of game play when playtesting and I think that rushing too fast can mean you miss out on some stuff, that being said when you have leveled a character to 15+ so many times certain areas/regions get repetitive (ie Moathouse) and rushing through those levels can have merit, although personally I like to know how my character fares against the bosses of certain areas compared with other builds I've played...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
We do play a roleplaying game, but this is a character builders guild, not a roleplayer guild. 
Some people accuse people such as us of abysmally sinful acts such as powergaming, munching, griefing and meta-gaming, as opposed to the just and honest persuit of immersive and consistent character-portraying roleplay.
I say each to his own.
Both role- and roll playing has its own rewards.
I enjoy the power of a well built character build. I also enjoy the immersion of playing a well designed module and the shared fun of portraying different characters and interacting with them in good roleplay on a PW.
Some people say these things cannot be combined or united. I say they can. 
There are good and bad builds and there is good and bad roleplay. It is possible to enjoy both and even be good at both.
You don't have to be a bad roleplayer to be a good builder or a bad builder to be a good roleplayer. That is just the stereotypical thinking of some people.

If you want to roleplay a character with flaws, (a thing that sometimes can make roleplaying more interesting,) a good builder is able to create a build with those flaws.
But strictly speaking, you don't even need a buildat all, if all you want to do is to portray a character/personality. You only need an avatar to be able to act. That can be as simple as a level 1 character of any class. You can roleplay being a mage without ever casting a spell in public. You can pretend to be a soldier, never picking up a sword when on leave, etc. etc.
But once you want to go out there hacking and slashing, then you need a build that can handle it. And that is what is our business, roleplayers or not.

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
Just a little more information about the crafting system on WoG.  It uses an enhanced system that allows the wands and scrolls to scale to high levels than in the Vanilla game.  This does come with a caveat though.  The scrolls/wands are then class specific.  In vanilla NWN, any arcane class can use a scribed arcane scroll.  In WoG, if a Bard makes a scroll of Improved Invis, it will be tagged as Bard only.  

So since we are talking about UMD, I dont know off the top of my head how this affects the UMD requirement for using a particular scroll.  Just figured I'd make sure you were aware of the difference from normal scribing/wand making.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Running to Kobolds breaks immersion for me, it's pretty far and dangerous to get there too.
I am curious about why you say this.

Let us say one has done the Moathouse.  Solo, one is around level 5~7, dependingly.  One has access to at least a potion of invis if it was not used up in the Moathouse.

That one invis potion will get one easily past the Bandits between Hommlet and Greyhawk City.  From there, it is south until the Crossroads.  From there, there are some animals in the way, but they are easily avoidable if one so chooses, etc.

On Horseback, it is even easier and faster.

There is nothing else in the way.

Now, I can uderstand the breaking of immersion.  That is a valid point.

Logically, the natural tendency would be to follow the leads to Nulb and ToEE from Hommlet.  After that, one is in GH City and the PW is open to exploration.

However, from difficulty and xp pov, it makes more sense to go to BK after Hommlet solo.

The main reason for this disparity is rather simple - WoG was created with Party play in mind, and BK was part of the original PW way back when.

It is not a "typical" module for offline solo play.  As of now, it actually has 4 starting areas (Hommlet, BK, Saltmarsh, and Ruskis).  This is a good thing, as traffic can mean that a particular area is being visited (in the case that someone or a party does not wish to be disturbed by others) and one can go to another area.

To be honest, after completing Hommlet and ToEE, there is really no tie-in to any of the other content on WoG.  Same goes for Saltmarsh, and Ruskis for that matter.  BK, being from the original PW, does have a tie in with the Dragon Cult and UM.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
I suppose one of my issues, Webshaman, with the list is I tend to be at a completely different level than you.  I start the Kobolds (and the Wild Coast by extension) at Level 2, not Level 5-7.  For me BK is a starting point for a new character, just like Hommlet or Ruskis (or the new Saltmarsh).  But One doesn't need to do Hommlet and then run all the way to Borderkeep.

Likewise when I complete Hommlet I am Level 4.  I then begin the Temple of EE and if/when I make it through there, I'm about Level 14.  From there one can go any number of directions -- Cairn Hills, or Shield Lands, or the Steading of the Hill Giant Chief.

Similarily, one can start on Ruskis and take a completely different path.  Ruskis, Ghost Tower of Inverness, maybe some Assault on the Glacial Rift and then White Plume Mountain. 

I dislike the list because one, it's too linear and WoG is anything but, and two, if it get's bandied about enough it becomes dogma, and it really shouldn't be.

I would be more inclined to let Empyre flounder and make his way on his own, and let him develop his own list.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The list came about due to power level ideas (IMO).

That is, when soloing, how can I get the best "bang" for my "buck" (squeeze the most XP out of a run).

I personally have no problem with that list becoming dogma, because it is not the best way to power level on WoG.  It just lists what areas to do in sequence so one can get XP while adventuring solo. It should not be taken as the gospel, or best way to power level.

My personal "list" looks far, far different, and I am very confident that anyone who plays WoG for awhile solo will have their own, personal "list" custom fitted to their experiences and interests.  My personal list is pretty...far outside the box.

I have tried doing BK first, then progressing from there.  There are some advantages to doing it that way, but for the most part, Hommlet&Surrounds just has more stuff laying around, and easy for the taking.  YMMV. 

Also, the frogs, etc, of Hommlet are among the easiest and best foes that one can have on WoG for beginning levels.  No missle weapons, slow, easy to spot.  One can easily kite them on a Horse with any type of missle weapon, even with the huge malus to ranged on horseback.  It's insta-level.  Inside the Moathouse is pretty easy as well, especially the first level of it, and there is ample treasure, xp, etc for a solo player there.

Kobolds, Goblins, and Orcs, on the other hand (not to mention Gnolls) are killer for beginning players.  Even for experienced players, it's dirtnap city without the proper hps, protections, etc.  The opponents stealth, have magic, use missle weapons, and are in HUGE numbers.  And there are traps.  Without a solid, thought-out strategy and approach (and prior knowledge), one will dirtnap backwards xp wise.

Anyway, the list is just an aid, nothing more.

I'm done here.

Well, you're 20th level now, so you have a variety of options before you:

1. Go north to the Shield Lands and aid the folk in the Great Northern Crusade
2. Go north to the Shield Lands and only marginally aid them, but then turn west and head to White Plume Mountain.
3. Go to the Cairn Hills and investigate the Frost Giant menace (grab the quest from Pero at the Crossroads).
4. Go to the Bright Desert and investigate the mysteries there
5. Go to Undermountain and see how deep the rabbit hole goes

It's non-linear with lots of replayability.

This!

It took me about a year of playing and experience to realise there's no perfect quest order.

Depending on power of build, at any given level range, there's a choice of quests to move you forward.    One or more completed will take you out of range of the others.

So don't panic you've missed out, or done it wrong, just try the others next character around.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey guys! I have finally finished reading all 27 pages of this topic! Geezzuzz!!! 

I'd like to offer my 2 cents about a few of the things I read in my absence.

@Orion it's great to see how you went on your first exploration of WoG. I remember when I started there, it was truly fabulous!

@Stagmeister 

The thing about WoG is that there ARE opportunities for both kinds of players to find enjoyment. There are areas where you could powerlevel, but don't misconstrude the server as a place where group of maniac powerlevelers test different cheesy strategies. There are those who have fun doing that, and the server has areas where that can be done. However, a more RP-oriented player such as yourself CAN find plenty of enjoyment in the module.

You say you like to explore a module to "unravel" the story. On WoG there are MULTIPLE stories to unravel. I think how it differs from a SP module, is that instead of a linear story, you have MANY stories to choose from, which means you can play a character to level 40 doing some quests, then you can make another character, start in a different area, and do a completely different "quest route" and reach level 40 without repeating a single quest!! And these quests DO have well-constructed narratives and the epic ones DO feel epic. Or you can take the approach of an "explorer" and try to level up by exploring Undermountain, RPing that your character's goal is to "unravel the secrets" of the world's most famous and dangerous dungeon. There is literally room for everyone.

@Empyre65 

If I were you, I wouldn't do all quests listed in that file in the order they're listed. I'd separate them into "bulks" and do multiple runs. Otherwise they might become too easy, because you'll be doing them at a higher level than you're supposed to. Like Grizz said, when you go to the Shield Lands at 20th level, you'll find TOUGH battles out there, and the boss battles will be truly epic! If you get there nearing level 30 (which invariably will happen if you follow that guide), then you'll only find challenge in the boss battles, and by the time you finish, you'll be level 40. IMO, the way to go when you're exploring the server is to feel what it's like and learn the quests at the level they're supposed to be played. Then, after you know, you can make your own list.

Here are a few routes you might want to follow:

1- You could start in Hommlet into ToEE into Gang Menace, into High Seas Justice, into Recovery of the Light, into Public Crypts, into Muddy Bird (all Bold quests are in GH), into Hill Giants, into Frost Giants, into Duergar Caves, into Manscorpion King, into Volte. This will probably get you to early-mid 20s and you'll finish up in the desert. Then from there there are many options.

2- You could start in Borderkeep, do all quests there (Kobolds, Goblins, Orcs and Gnolls), into Kron Necromancer, into Dragon Cult Caves, into Bandit Chief Ashalt, into Hugo the Bandit King, into Ghost Tower of Inverness, into Scorpion Crown into Dragon Cult GH and Dino Island into Shield Lands.

Then the 3rd character could start at Ruskis and do Shipwreck's quests, Fish Head Menace, etc... by then you should have sufficient knowledge of the server to make your own quest route. You'll also have your favorite quests that you don't want to miss for the world. I for example LOVE the Ghost Tower of Inverness quest. I never miss it. It's SO COOL!!

There are multiple quests one can do. My advice is to do them at the level they're supposed to be done at least once, to see how challenging they are and test yourself to overcome the challenges. No matter how well-balanced a server is, if you do a 12th level quest at level 20, it WILL be too easy. Now, if you're able to finish ToEE at level 14 like Grizz, then you can call yourself a truly EPIC adventurer.

That's my 2 cents!

Empyre65 wrote:I just hopped into the game to check, and I do have them and I am (figuratively) kicking myself for not using them.
This was one of the first things that playing on WoG taught me back in the day. Swapping gear. If you want to be effective on WoG, you need to save many situational items and use them as the situation requires. Among them, but not restricted to, are:

Belt of Guiding Light for Death Immunity
Lesser Belt of Guiding Light for Fear Immunity
Greater Archer's Belt for Resistance to Piercing
Greater Slasher's Belt for Resistance to Slashing
Brawler's Belt (Greater Brawler's if you can find one) for Resistance to Bludgeoning
Ring of Freedom
Belt of Agility for Freedom
Scorpion Ring for Poison Immunity
KD immunity boots (until you can get your hands on a good set of boots that have it as a property)
Ring of Elemental Resistance

Etc...

Then, when the situation calls for a specific item, don't be afraid to swap out your STR belt or boots for an Immunity. It'll make your life a lot easier!

Hey man!

Congratulaions on your victory against Lord Arbas!
SpoilerYou can proceed further West right now, but save your game before entering that screen. It's the only bugged area on WoG. Just take a quick hike around Castle Hart, but you can't go in because they never fixed it before moving WoG to EE. Over there it's working well. So, what you're looking for is a corpse that has an item called Love Letter. Find it and take it to Vaalstinean's Bardic College, to an NPC named Lady Illuvien. That'll wrap up the West quests.
To the East, there is a VAST expanse to explore. The scenery and area design is BREATHTAKING, the enemies are EPIC and there are some VERY TOUGH bosses to be found. There are several aras to explore, which I will list below for your reference:
SpoilerThe Great Northern Crusade part is kiling Waquinos inside Docamald Keep. It may be a little annoying to get the drawbridge lowered, but you can figure it out. Inside, you'll also find the Chalice of Heironeous, which needs to be delivered to Count Franz Thorkeep in the Critwall Castle for another quest.
 
SpoilerThe Great Effluvial Swamp and surroundings. There is only one "quest", which is probably the most annoying one to complete. There are also many areas to explore, which are awesome adventures, but not quests per se (meaning they don't have a Journal entry associated with them): - The Effluvial Swamp - Bottom of the Pit - Stone Giant Caves - White Plume Mountain (possibly the one you thought was in the West). You'll need a few Search-boosting items to successfully complete this one.
If you decide to do the whole East in one go, it'll be a VERY LONG adventure, so pack a lunch! Also, if you do that, leave the Heart of the Swamp for last. You'll know why when you get there (just trying to save you the annoyance). PM me if you'd like more details. 

Alternatively, you can just do the Great Northern Crusade and then head towards the North. That's the beauty of WoG. You can choose the order. :D

This is EPIC. I think you'll LOVE it! Cheers!

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
Sep 27, 2020
I have always assumed that offensive spells cast from scrolls would have such low caster level and low DC that they would not be useful, especially against bosses.  Even after all these years, I am still learning new things.
Breach spells have ZERO chance of failing. The only chance a Breach won't breach anything is if there isn't anything to be breached. The difference between Lesser and Greater Spell Breach is the number of protective spells removed, and the amount by which Spell Resistance is lowered (2 and 4 respectively). Do you know the order in which these spells are removed? I ask this because in battles where enemies have multiple protective buffs (and you're going to run into a few of them from now on, that's a good way to decide whether to cast Lesser Spell Breach, Greater Spell Breach or even Mordenkainen's Disjunction.

Here's a link to the Wiki:

https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Breach

The spells will remove these protections counting from 1-32 until it removes its maximum number of spells, and then the remaining protections will stay active. So, if the enemy has many protections at the same time, these will require multiple breaches, especially because Mestil's Acid Sheath is only number 14 on the list.

For this battle, just Lesser Spell Breach should suffice, since she only casts that one buff.

Good luck! Post a screenshot after your victory, will you?

Cheers!

There is the area down there, which congrats on beating. That is a very cool enemy IMO. Not the hardest, but definitely one of the coolest!

Then there is another area up the other side of the cliff, near an alcove with two stone giants and two shadow manticores, which you need a Rope of Climbing to access. You can buy one from the merchant in the group you met. That rope will probably be lost to you if you backtrack on foot, as there is no way to retrieve the rope from below once you throw it. Then, up the opposite side of the canyon is the lair of the Stone Giant King. Really nice adventure there! After that you can backtrack to the swamp and do the Heart of the Swamp. However, I must warn you that it's possible this quest is bugged too. Try to avoid using summons when you have the Earl with you and you'll have higher chances of success.

I have been able to complete it with one toon, but when I tried with another, it got screwed up somewhere. I don't know where...

posts.author: Steniel
posts.content:
Hello guys, I have somewhat wog-build related question

Playing an arcane archer cleric with supllemental casting of 12-16 lvl in final build. Struggling with domain decision

1) travel-trickery is a default one
2) summons are superstrong early, but I guess will be weaker later and at 40. Are they viable lategame? Should even consider them to so some tanking job there?

Hence questions:
- is animal worth considering for summon buff? There is no option to pair it with trickery or travel though. War, plant and earth are somewhat usefull.

- are spell lvl 8-9 summons strong enogh to get more caster lvls at the cost of lowering AB from naked 50 in my plan to 45-47 range?

Archer with summons looks so strong early lvls but I have doubts investing in them for end build

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
Summons can be very viable when one uses animal domain and buffs them up. Making a build that can buff up their ac might be not be conducive to making an archer, however. Feats up to and including greater spell focus conjuration might not be what one is looking to do. Even without animal domain and the focus feats, the level 9 water and fire elementals can last in many later areas, but not all, and not all the time. Improved invisibility, haste,mage armor, empowered dex, are all what I do with my summoner mages, at the very least.

The summons one gets when you have the animal domain are one level higher, and when you can get the elemental nobility line, they can be very tanky and stay alive for quite a while, even at higher levels.

Then again they can also be dispelled/dismissed. Always a good time to buff up some help and then have it gone instantly :)

Generally I always like to have my archers with 55+ ab. Tenser's transformation is not vanilla on WoG, and can boost your ab, but it really shines with a lot of caster levels.

It probably would be good to know what build you are considering tweaking. Does it have access to UMD? Or is it the standard Fighter/wizard/arcane archer? I assume that it takes called shot?

Edit. Actually you must be a cleric or druid/wizardor bard/arcane archer? I'll leave this as is, to showcase my inability to think straight when I am sleep deprived.

Edit: For a cleric arcane archer, travel and trickery are nice domains, but then again you're not going to have enough caster levels to have a long duration on haste, nor be undispellable for the improved invis. Make sure you get a haste wand and improved invisibility. Buy them from another player. That's what I'd do myself, I'd go animal and plant, and don't be shy about asking someone to craft some wands for you. Make sure that if you are bard, that you have enough UMD to use the wands.

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
With 1 wizard level, you'll have access to wizard wands. That will be a big help.
Being experienced with the server, I myself would take bard, and just eat the xp hit. I don't like the idea of losing those skill points cross classing tumble!
I tend to play my archers as low hp cannons myself. It will be fun to shred enemies with your damage, just be ready to get out of there.
I'd encourage you to find a way to get some set trap. It's always nice to have some traps down to slow down enemies, or kill them when they start to rush your archer.
Deadly traps are mostly dc 35 to set. Tangle will slow enemies down, and fire and electricity will teach them to rush you. There are items to help with crafting and setting traps. Rings and such. Personally I'd drop the spell craft to get these myself.

I'd be tempted to go bard for more skill points, some UMD. With that UMD I'd be on the lookout for using druid scrolls, camo and one with the land. Give some nice bonuses to hide and move silently.

I don't mean to preach on with what I'd do so much. I'm not so sure you want/need so much advice.
.

"(btw, are there any good exotic weapon builds for WoG?)"

Mercurial greatsword builds are one of my favorites, and those one can basically take any scythe build and just replace Mercurial greatsword. On Wog, Mercurial greatsword is not as good as a scythe, being that it only does slashing damage by default, not slashing and piercing like the scythe.

There are some good mercurial greatsword dedicated drops out there, and I've had some characters reach level 40 without ever getting a good legendary/etc Mercurial greatsword or six socket, and I had a lot of fun playing them nonetheless.

Did you have anything specific in mind?

posts.content:
Let me once more rephrase my socket question according to rules

It is obvious that there are a variety of properties, and as I understand, discussing something like "For build X I prefer property Y on item Z is fine, because I've seen such discussion's on WoG's tapatalk.

So the question is what properties are typical for armor for melee builds? For example, we don't want waste the gems for a socketed gauntlet on a 2h build, because that slot is reserved for shielding bracers, which are a must. Necklace is for natural armor. Boots are for haste. Hence we'd better spend our precious gems on some other item. So that is the kind of "best practices" I'd like to know

Which stats do we want for a multiple socket cloak for example? Freedom comes to mind for example. Do we want regen on a main items or it's better to make a separate "regen item set" to replenish health outside a fight without having to rest? or may be it is worth spending a slot in each socketed item to get this regen during battles?

I realize I'll only see answers if that doesn't break the "DM Wise Law"

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Alright, this is more inline with what the rules and guidelines allow.

Anything that does not have a +6 type effect should be the focus of your Socket Items (not including weapons here).

So, depending on the build, this means Rings, Belts, Helms, and Bracers/Gloves.

As for what to put on them, I think the obvious candidates are immunities, stats, /DR, Regen and Other.  I'm not going to go into the particulars of "Other" here.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
There are several ways to do it.

One involves wands, the other involves abusing Druids.  Of course, one can do both!

I will say that a Cleric/Druid/Rog is amazingly powerful, if built correctly.  I used that build to basically do the "no bling Undermountain nekkid challenge" - meaning you only get your starting gear, and have to basically find whatever you can in UM (and you can only adventure there).  Got to level 32.  Oh, and it was Iron Man as well, so...no dying, or you start over fresh with a new PC.

Then the meta-knowledge comes into play.  Knowing what where is, and how to kill it without dying (and getting massive XP awards for doing so).

It's basically a bit of meta-knowledge combined with MOAR firepower (which is basically your orderve).

My advice is always, first get a PC to level 40 by exploring and levelling on WoG, before you try fast levelling.  That will give you some working knowledge of WoG, and help you avoid some newbie mistakes.

But for the build above, you want to stack your Domains so that you "rule the roost" so to speak - so a Half-Elf (they get Wis+1 on WoG) Cleric of Sehanine Moonbow (Travel and Trickery!), with 1 level Druid (Animal Domain, yeah baby! Improved summons, what's not to like about that?) AND take Spell Focus : Conjuration AND pick up Greater Spell Focus : Conjuration (cuz, you know, better summons doubleplusgood!).

Now you can use wands and scrolls from both Cleric and Druid sources (yeah, that's a hint), as well as wands of the same nature.  Picking up a Rog level somewhere along the line will add UMD to your list of goodness, which basically means "WOOOOHOOOOO! Give it to me, baby!" and you are ready to rocket up in levels.

Oh, well, yeah, it's super-mega-cheesey, sure.  But, you know, if you like cheese like I do, well...enjoy!

Best thing about it?  Yeah, maybe you noticed - NO XP PENALTY!  Holy crud Webbie, how'd you do it?  Yeah, just keep your Druid and Rog levels roughly equal and you can be a Playah too!  Besides, you want MOAR than 1 Druid level, for that beautiful immunity to Web, Entangle, and Grease, right??!!  And Rog levels just gives you dumps GALORE!  And Uncanny Dodge.  And SA.  And Tumble.  And Open Locks, Disarm, which goes really well with your Trickery Domain!

Yeah, it's sick!
